If `Œ±` is a second countable Borel space with a linear order and order topology, every countable family of measurable functions from a measurable space `Œ¥` to `Œ±` having the property that each element of `Œ¥` is the greatest lower bound of the set of values of the family at some index, then the function that maps each element of `Œ¥` to its greatest lower value is measurable.

type:
‚àÄ {Œ± : Type u_1} {Œ¥ : Type u_5} [inst : TopologicalSpace Œ±] [inst_1 : MeasurableSpace Œ±] [inst_2 : BorelSpace Œ±]
  [inst_3 : MeasurableSpace Œ¥] [inst_4 : LinearOrder Œ±] [inst_5 : OrderTopology Œ±] [inst : SecondCountableTopology Œ±]
  {Œπ : Sort u_6} [inst : Countable Œπ] {f : Œπ ‚Üí Œ¥ ‚Üí Œ±} {g : Œ¥ ‚Üí Œ±},
  (‚àÄ (i : Œπ), Measurable (f i)) ‚Üí (‚àÄ (b : Œ¥), IsGLB {a | ‚àÉ i, f i b = a} (g b)) ‚Üí Measurable g
name: Measurable.isGLB
docString: If `Œ±` is a second countable Borel space with a linear order and order topology, every countable family of measurable functions from a measurable space `Œ¥` to `Œ±` having the property that each element of `Œ¥` is the greatest lower bound of the set of values of the family at some index, then the function that maps each element of `Œ¥` to its greatest lower value is measurable.

This theorem, known as the **Extreme Value Theorem**, states that for any function `f` from a set `Œ≤` to a linearly ordered set `Œ±`, given that `f` is continuous on a closed subset `s` of `Œ≤` and that for any element `x‚ÇÄ` in `s`, `f`'s value at `x‚ÇÄ` is greater than its value at almost all points of `Œ≤` not in compact subsets and in `s`, there exists an element in `s` at which `f` attains its maximum. The conditions on `f` and `s` ensure that `f` behaves well within `s` and that `s` is a well-behaved topological space. In mathematical terms, it says that if a function is continuous on a closed set and it is smaller than a value in its image away from compact sets, then it has a maximum on this set.

type:
‚àÄ {Œ± : Type u_2} {Œ≤ : Type u_3} [inst : LinearOrder Œ±] [inst_1 : TopologicalSpace Œ±] [inst_2 : TopologicalSpace Œ≤]
  [inst_3 : ClosedIciTopology Œ±] {s : Set Œ≤} {f : Œ≤ ‚Üí Œ±},
  ContinuousOn f s ‚Üí
    IsClosed s ‚Üí
      ‚àÄ {x‚ÇÄ : Œ≤}, x‚ÇÄ ‚àà s ‚Üí (‚àÄ·∂† (x : Œ≤) in Filter.cocompact Œ≤ ‚äì Filter.principal s, f x ‚â§ f x‚ÇÄ) ‚Üí ‚àÉ x ‚àà s, IsMaxOn f s x
name: ContinuousOn.exists_isMaxOn'
docString: This theorem, known as the **Extreme Value Theorem**, states that for any function `f` from a set `Œ≤` to a linearly ordered set `Œ±`, given that `f` is continuous on a closed subset `s` of `Œ≤` and that for any element `x‚ÇÄ` in `s`, `f`'s value at `x‚ÇÄ` is greater than its value at almost all points of `Œ≤` not in compact subsets and in `s`, there exists an element in `s` at which `f` attains its maximum. The conditions on `f` and `s` ensure that `f` behaves well within `s` and that `s` is a well-behaved topological space. In mathematical terms, it says that if a function is continuous on a closed set and it is smaller than a value in its image away from compact sets, then it has a maximum on this set.

If a differentiable function `f` is approximated by a linear map `A` on a set `s`, up to `Œ¥`,
then at almost every `x` in `s` one has `‚Äñf' x - A‚Äñ ‚â§ Œ¥`.

name: ApproximatesLinearOn.norm_fderiv_sub_le
docString:

For any seminormed additive commutative group E, subset s, and real number Œ¥, the set {x : E | ‚à•x‚à• ‚â§ Œ¥ ‚à® x ‚àà s} equals the set {x : E | ‚à•x - o ‚à• ‚â§ Œ¥}, where o is the origin of E.

docString: For any seminormed additive commutative group E, subset s, and real number Œ¥, the set {x : E | ‚à•x‚à• ‚â§ Œ¥ ‚à® x ‚àà s} equals the set {x : E | ‚à•x - o ‚à• ‚â§ Œ¥}, where o is the origin of E.

This theorem states that for any non-empty finite set `s` of type `Œ≤` and any function `f` from `Œ≤` to `Œ±` (where `Œ±` is a linearly ordered type), there exists an element `x` in `s` such that the image of `x` under `f` is greater than or equal to the image of any other element in `s` under `f`. In other words, `f(x)` is the maximum value attained by `f` on `s`.

In other words, `f(x)` is the maximum value attained by `f` on `s`.

`Metric.closedBall x (Œ¥ x) ‚äÜ U i`.
